was established in 1938 in Mexico City. It attracted a group of pathbreaking
scholars in the humanities and social science
provided an outlet for their work, which
foregrounded some of the ongoing lines of inquiry in Mexican and Latin American
studies, including scholarship on migration to and from
church and state in Latin America, and women’s rights.
press published its first title in
work throughout its history. The list of the press spans disciplines in the
qualitative social sciences, with special emphases on history, sociology, literary criticism,
and political science. For the most part, the books focus on Mexican and Latin American
In addition to a robust books program, the press of
arguably the leading journal of Mexican
historical studies. Over time, the press has also been an important outlet for making
language writing available in Mexico: as one example,
the first to publish Milan Kundera's work in Spanish for a Mexican audience.
Since 2013, Colmex’s press has published some of its new books in digital form and
them through digital scholarly platforms, including JSTOR. Like many
established scholarly presses, Colmex licenses access to its frontlist titles to university
libraries to help sustain its ongoing publishing program.

JSTOR normally receives and processes PDFs from publishers.  These PDFs
go through automated workflows at JSTOR’s end as well as processing by a third
vendor.  This project was different because the source document for eac
, and one of the required outputs was an ePub for each book.  JSTOR
selected one of our current conversion vendors, Apex CoVantage, to handle all vendor
processing for the books in the project.  This include
shipment of the print copy to Colmex, creation of the PDF from the page images, OCR
for creation of searchable full text, metadata capture to JSTOR standard specification for
books, and then creation of an ePub.  JSTOR negotiated a per page
covered all these tasks.  The p
shipments of print books to Apex CoVantage’s production facility in
Hyderabad, India.  The initial batch was shipped mid
April 2018, and the final batch was
May 2019.  Each shipment contained an average of 76 print books.  Apex
destructive scanning with each page scanned as 600 dpi bitonal TIFF
Although JSTOR has scanned a relatively small number of print books outside this project, the bulk of our print scanning
continues to be for journals.  However, the same
specifications are used regardless of whether they are journal or

and grayscale/color content scanned at 300 dpi for RGB TIFF images.  We instituted a
y process wherein Apex reported damaged, missing, or other problematic
pages to JSTOR.  JSTOR assessed these reports and, as needed, worked with Colmex,
and University of Michigan Library collections to locate and
nt pages from other extant copies.  The resulting page scans were then
used in place of the damaged or otherwise unusable pages or to fill gaps where there

Apex submitted the completed PDFs to JSTOR and shipped the print copies back to
Colmex.  JSTOR’s systems then ingested the PDF as well as spreadsheet
chain metadata (SCM) provided separately by Colmex.  The PDF and SCM were matched
system and then were automatically sent to Apex for standard processing

As Apex completed the standard processing for each book, they then put the books
process that, while very familiar to Apex, was new to JSTOR.
The ePubs were created to the EPUB standard version 3.0.1 or higher.  Additionally, the
processing agreed upon between Apex and JSTOR ensured functionality such as links
the text block to the footnotes themselves.  However, features
such as tables were captured as images rather than as HTML.  During both the standard
processing and ePub creation, Apex occasionally raised metadata capture queries
thus ensuring a higher and more consistent quality for
Apex grouped the ePub, the PDF, and the book
file for delivery to JSTOR.  JSTOR systems then ingested the zip file and ran
quality control scripts across the files to ensure that they adhered to our specifications.
For the initial batch of books, we also conducted a limited amount of manual quality
control reviews of the metadata and of the ePub.

ISBN assignments, and the JSTOR systems require an ISBN.
logistical challenges, the challenges that were
The need to send the books to one particular vendor instead of dividing them
equally between our two vendors, which was addre
The lack of electronic version ISBN (EISBN) assignments for any of the book
ISBN best practice indicates that an electronic version of a book should have an ISBN
that is distinct from its print version counterpart. In fact, different electronic versions
(e.g., PDF vs. EPUB) can have their own ISBN assignments.  However, JSTOR
use a single ISBN assignment to cover both electronic versions of each book.  Going into
the project, Colmex did not have EISBN assignments for the books, and 102 of the books
did not have a print version ISBN (PISBN) either.  One problem was tha
published works, the ISBN are assigned by a third
times for the assignments, particularly for large batches of requests, are unpredictable.
not to jeopardize the overall timeframe for the proje
the PSIBN for any book that had a PISBN assignment.  This would allow us to ingest the
supply chain metadata into JSTOR systems and to keep individual book processing
apply for EISBN assignments attempting to prioritize the
assignments for those books that had no ISBN assignment at all.  For books that had no
ISBN assignment at all, we could move them back into production post
For books that had a PISBN assignment, we plan to do a
mass swap of the PISBN for the EISBN once we ha
all those assignments.  At the time
books were still awaiting an EISBN assignment
assignment at all and that therefore cannot proceed
We are currently planning a project to swap the PISBN for the EISBN for those books
where we have the EISBN assignments.  We will finish the processing and/or ISBN
he remaining books when the EISBN assignments are available.  If we were to
list books, we would certainly investigate the
EISBN situation at the earliest possible stage and work with project partners to secure
BN assignments as soon as possible.

The Colmex titles digitized through this project have been heavily use
680 titles made available on JSTOR between September 2018 and July 2019 have been
used a total of 502,134 times through October 28, 2019. Every single title has been used.
pact of Open Access Latin American Scholarship
Historia económica general de México: de la

Los intelectuales y el poder en México
Diccionario del español usual en México

Historia general de México: volumen II
The data show that there is a broad audience for this scholarship. The titles have been
in 173 countries and territories. While high levels of usage were recorded in
speaking countries, as we expected, usage also occurred in 161 countries and
territories where Spanish is not a national or official language. The map below shows the
untries in which we have recorded usage for the Colmex titles, and the table lists the
ten countries with the highest usage.
pact of Open Access Latin American Scholarship
Top ten countries that recorded the most usage

Because JSTOR works with thousands of institutions around the world, we can measure
the usage of these titles at institutions that participate in our services. We recorded usage
of the Colmex titles at 4,285 institutions.  This included not only
but also community colleges, secondary schools, government and not

The 684 digitized titles will be openly available to the Mexican people
and promoted as part of this project.
This project also built a foundation for continued work on the Open Access
dissemination of Latin American scholarship. JSTOR is currently parti
led by the Latin American Research Resources Project (LARRP), a consortium of
research libraries that is funding the Open Access distribution of 200 titles published in
2019 by the Latin American Council of Social Sciences (CLACSO)
developed and supported by libraries, will test a framework for the sustainable, long
term stewardship of Open Access scholarly monographs.
We are grateful that the Humanities Open Book program grant
provided the opportunity for JSTOR to partner with El Colegio de
México to make its important scholarship available for researchers around the world to
discover and use. We look forward to continuing to build on what we’ve achieved
